headline.main: Space Shuttle Crew Gave Sleep a Fast Shuffle

results.snippet: Their flight in the space shuttle Columbia had been cut back from five days to two, so Col. Joe H. Engle and Capt. Richard H. Truly decided to do some cutting back of their own - on their sleep schedules.   During part of the time they were...

byline.original: By Albin Krebs and Robert McG. Thomas

results.lead_paragraph: Their flight in the space shuttle Columbia had been cut back from five days to two, so Col. Joe H. Engle and Capt. Richard H. Truly decided to do some cutting back of their own - on their sleep schedules. During part of the time they were supposed to be sleeping, the astronauts said, they were taking pictures of the passing scenery.

results.snippet: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1980. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings....
results.lead_paragraph: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1980. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The New York Times Book Review. Autobiography & Biography THE ALCOTTS. Biography of a Family. By Madelon Bedell. (Clarkson Potter, $15.95.) A ''charming popular biography'' of Bronson Alcott - the noted abolitionist and educator who was a friend of Emerson, Thoreau and Channing - and of his wife, Abigail May, and their daughter, Louisa May. ALICE JAMES. A Biography. By Jean Strouse. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.) A ''judicious and beautifully written'' full-length study of the sister of William and Henry James, the only daughter in the talented, eccentric American family.

headline.main: ASTRONAUT TRIP FROM SPACE SHUTTLE PLANNED

results.snippet: The first manned excursion outside the space shuttle will be straight out of science fiction: An astronaut propelled by a jet-powered backpack moving out to an ailing $75 million satellite, bringing it into the ship's cargo bay, fixing it and...
results.lead_paragraph: The first manned excursion outside the space shuttle will be straight out of science fiction: An astronaut propelled by a jet-powered backpack moving out to an ailing $75 million satellite, bringing it into the ship's cargo bay, fixing it and putting it back into orbit. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration disclosed the plan Wednesday in discussing the future of the shuttle before the Senate Subcommittee on Science, Technology and Space. The flight, to be made in 1983, will be an early demonstration of the shuttle's satellite servicing capabilities while in orbit and will revive a payload of great value to solar scientists around the world.

results.snippet: Seymour Topping is the managing editor of The New York Times. Audrey Topping, the author of ''The Splendors of Tibet,'' collaborated in the reporting of this article. By Seymour Topping   The Soviet TU-154 airliner soars over the snowcapped...
results.lead_paragraph: Seymour Topping is the managing editor of The New York Times. Audrey Topping, the author of ''The Splendors of Tibet,'' collaborated in the reporting of this article. By Seymour Topping The Soviet TU-154 airliner soars over the snowcapped wastelands of Central Asia and settles upon a yellow, grassland plateau. An official car carries us from the small airport past grazing horses, cattle and yaks; beside tiny wooden houses and the conical, tentlike dwellings - wool felt stretched on pine frames - known as yurts; over the Tola River, already glistening with a sheen of ice on this October day, and on into a wide valley. Suddenly, the skyline of a modern city juts above the horizon: High-rise apartment houses in pastel shades, swaying construction cranes, spewing factory smokestacks. We have arrived in Ulan Bator, a city of 400,000 people and the capital of the Mongolian People's Republic. Men and women in traditional long, padded gowns tied with silk sashes share crowded sidewalks with modish young women in smart, Western-style leather jackets and high-heeled boots. A lone Buddhist lama in saffron robes hurries past strolling Russian soldiers on leave from posts on the Chinese frontier.

headline.main: POLISH COUNCIL MEMBERS HAVE CLOSE SOVIET TIES

results.snippet: The Military Council for National Salvation that has taken over in Poland comprises political generals, key officers within the Ministry of National Defense, and strategically placed military commanders.   The 21 men on the council, under the...

byline.original: By RICHARD HALLORAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Military Council for National Salvation that has taken over in Poland comprises political generals, key officers within the Ministry of National Defense, and strategically placed military commanders. The 21 men on the council, under the direction of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, are considered by United States Government and academic specialists on Poland to come from the main line of professional officers within the Polish army but to have close ties with the Soviet Union. Some were said to prefer keeping out of politics, while others favored a hard line with the unions. Several are seasoned veterans of combat.

results.snippet: One of Handel's greatest operas, ''Orlando,'' was given what is being called its American premiere here last night. That is noteworthy, as is the fact that it is being presented by Robert Brustein's American Repertory Theater, for 34 performances...

byline.original: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: One of Handel's greatest operas, ''Orlando,'' was given what is being called its American premiere here last night. That is noteworthy, as is the fact that it is being presented by Robert Brustein's American Repertory Theater, for 34 performances in repertory through March 14. And for a third claim to fame, the production is by the enfant terrible of New England opera and theater direction, Peter Sellars. ''Orlando'' is full of beautiful, psychologically true and formally daring music, and it should be said right away that the musical performance here is of the highest quality. The opera is presented virtually complete, with nearly three hours of music. The 14-member pit band under Craig Smith's direction plays with style, spirit and accuracy.
